tit.cmt: 蔵はstoreではなくstorehouseが適訳と思われます。

sen.j: 蔵奉行（くらぶぎょう）は、江戸時代に江戸浅草（浅草御蔵）をはじめとする主要都市にあった幕府の御米蔵の管理を司った奉行。
sen.e: Kura-bugyo was an administrator who controlled the government rice storehouses located in major cities in the Edo period, including one in Asakusa, Edo (Asakusa Okura).

sen.j: 勘定奉行の支配下にあり、役料200俵、焼火の間席。
sen.e: Under the control of kanjo-bugyo (commissioner of finance), kura-bugyo was posted to Takuhi-no-ma room receiving yakuryo (executive allowance) of 200 bales of rice.
sen.cmt: 「焼火の間」の読みは「たくひのま」と「たきびのま」が見受けられますが、勝部真長というお茶の水女子大名誉教授がその著「勝海舟」のなかで使用しておられる「たくひのま」を採用しています。

sen.j: 属僚として組頭、手代、門番同心、小揚者などがあった。
sen.e: Kura-bugyo's subordinates included kumigashira (head of the group), tedai (clerk), monban-doshin (gatekeeping constable) and koagemono (rice unloading laborer).
sen.cmt: 門番同心：定訳不明です。小揚者：読み不明ですが他に読みようがないと思われます。また定訳も不明で、意味からこのような仮訳をつけました。

sen.j: 蔵奉行という言葉の初出は慶長15年（1610年）とされ、江戸の浅草御蔵の成立は元和6年（1620年）成立と言われている。
sen.e: The first appearance of the word 'kura-bugyo' is said to have been 1610 and Asakusa Okura in Edo is said to have been established in 1620.

sen.j: ただし、蔵奉行の組織の成立は経済的先進地であった上方の方が先んじており、大坂では元和7年（1621年）、京都では寛永2年（1625年、ただし寛政2年（1790年）までは京都町奉行支配下）、江戸では寛永13年（1636年）の事であった。
sen.e: However, the kura-bugyo system was established earlier in the economically advanced area, i.e. Kamigata (Kyoto-Osaka area) - to be specific, in 1621 in Osaka, in 1625 in Kyoto (being under the control of Kyoto machi-bugyo or Kyoto City Magistrate till 1790) and in 1636 in Edo.

However, the kura-bugyo system was established earlier in the economically advanced area of Kamigata - to be specific, in 1621 in Osaka and in 1625 in Kyoto (being under the control of Kyoto machi-bugyo or Kyoto City Magistrate till 1790), while it was not until in 1636 that the system was established in Edo.
sen.cmt: 上方の括弧内の説明は後続の文章と重複するので削除しました。

sen.j: また一時期は駿河国清水市・近江国大津市・摂津国高槻市にも設置されたが、幕末まで存続したのは江戸・京都・大坂の3ヶ所のみである。
sen.e: In addition, kura-bugyo was established once in Shimizu City of Suruga Province, Otsu City of Omi Province and Takatsuki City of Settsu Province, but only three, namely ones in Edo, Kyoto and Osaka, continued to exist till the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 何百石取りというように知行地のある地方知行の旗本とは別に、三十俵二人扶持というように蔵米から3季に分けて切米を俸禄として貰う御家人（一部の旗本も含む）たちがいた。
sen.e: In addition to hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogun) who are provided with jigata-chigyo (provision of a fief to retainers as salary) as referred to as 'holding a fief yielding such and such koku of rice', there were gokenin (who are also direct retainers of the shogun) and some hatamoto who received 'kirimai' (an annual stipend of rice) in three seasonal installments from 'kuramai' (rice stocked in the government storehouses) as in a description such as 'receiving 30 bales of rice and a ration for two people.'

sen.e: These retainers were called 'kuramai-chigyo-dori' or 'kuramai-dori' (rice stipend receivers), and kura-bugyo was in charge of control of this rice stock.

sen.j: 蔵米取りの御家人は自家消費分以外の切米（米穀）を、御米蔵の前に店を構える札差を通じて現金化した。
sen.e: Kuramai-dori type of gokenin converted surplus rice over and above their own consumption through fudasashi (Tokugawa-period merchants who obtained the right to provide cash on the security of a vassal's rice stipends) who had their shops in front of government rice storehouses.
